Appeared to sinful flesh! who's here! His face
Speaks him Adorni! but some glorious angel
Concealing its divinity in his shape,
Hath done this miracle, it being not an act
For wolvish man. Resolve me, if thou lookest for
Bent knees in adoration?

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: O forbear sir,
I am Adorni, and the instrument
Of your deliverance; but the benefit
You owe another.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If he has a name,
As soon as spoken, 'tis writ on my heart,
I am his bondsman.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: To the shame of men,
This great act is a woman's.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The whole sex
For her sake must be deified. How I wander
In my imagination, yet cannot
Guess who this phoenix should be!

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: 'Tis Camiola.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pray you speak't again, there's music in her name
Once more I pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Camiola,
The maid of honour,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Cursed atheist that I was,
Only to doubt it could be any other,
Since she alone in the abstract of herself,
That small, but ravishing substance comprehends
Whatever is, or can be wished, in the
Judea of a woman. O what service,
Or sacrifice of duty can I pay her!
If not to live, and die her charity's slave,
Which is resolved already.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: She expects not
Such a dominion o'er you: yet ere I
Deliver her demands, give me your hand:
On this, as she enjoined me, with my lips
I print her love and service by me sent you,

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I am o'erwhelmed with wonder!

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: You must now
(Which is the sum of all that she desires)
By a solemn contract bind yourself, when she
Requires it as a debt, due for your freedom
To marry her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This does engage me further,
A payment! an increase of obligation!
To marry her! 'twas my nil ultra ever!
The end of my ambition! O that now
The holy man, she present, were prepared
To join our hands, but with that speed, my heart
Wishes, mine eyes might see her.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: You must swear this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Swear it? Collect all oaths, and imprecations
Whose least breach is damnation, and those
Ministered to me in a form more dreadful,
Set heaven, and hell before me, I will take 'em:
False to Camiola? Never. Shall I now
Begin my vows to you?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I am no churchman,
Such a one must file it on record, you are free,
And that you may appear like to yourself
(For so she wished) here's gold with which you may
Redeem your trunks and servants, and whatever
Of late you lost. I have found out the captain
Whose spoil they were. His name is Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know him.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I have done my parts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So much sir
as I am ever yours for't, now methinks
I walk in air! divine Camiola,
But words cannot express thee. I'll build to thee
An altar in my soul, on which I'll offer
A still increasing sacrifice of duty. Exit Ber●

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: What will become of me now is apparent!
Whether a poniard, or a halter be
The nearest way to hell (For I must thither,
After I have killed myself) is somewhat doubtful?
This Roman resolution of self-murder,
Will not hold water, at the high tribunal,
When it comes to be argued; my good genius
Prompts me to this consideration. He
That kills himself, to avoid misery, fears it,
And at the best shows but a bastard valour,
This life's a fort committed to my trust,
Which I must not yield up, till it be forced,
Nor will I: he's not valiant that dares die,
But he that boldly bears calamity.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Iv. a flourish.
div.stage: Pierio. Roderigo. Jacomo. Gonzaga. Aurelia. Ferdinand. Astutio. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Aurelia.
sp.l: A seat here for the Duke. It is our glory
To overcome with courtesies, not rigor;
To lordly roman, who held it the height
Of humane happiness, to have Kings and Queens
To wait by his triumphant chariot wheels
In his insulting pride, deprived himself
Of drawing near the nature of the gods,
Best known for such, in being merciful,
yet give me leave, but still with gentle language,
And with the freedom of a friend to tell you,
To seek by force, what courtship could not win,
Was not harsh, and never taught in love's mild school.
Wise poets feign that Venus' coach is drawn
By doves, and sparrows, not by bears, and tigers.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I spare the application.
In my fortune,
Heavens justice hath confirmed it, yet great lady,
Since my offence grew from excess of love,
And not to be resisted, having paid too,
With the loss of liberty, the forfeiture
Of my presumption, in your clemency
It may find pardon

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You shall have just cause
To say it hath. The charge of the long siege
Defrayed, and the loss my subjects have sustained
Made good, since so far I must deal with caution,
You have your liberty

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I could not hope for gentler conditions.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: My lord Gonzaga.
Since my coming to Sienna, I have heard much
Of your prisoner; brave Bertoldo.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: Such an one, madam, I had.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: And have still, sir, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Your hopes deceive you. He is ransomed madam,

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: By whom, I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: Gonzag.
sp.l: You had best inquire
Of your intelligencer. I am no informer.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: I like not this.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: He is, as 'tis reported,
A goodly gentleman, and of noble parts,
A brother of your order.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: He was, madam,
Till he against his oath wronged you, a Princess,
Which his religion bound him from.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Great minds
for trial of their valours oft maintain
Quarrels that are unjust, yet without malice,
And such a fair construction I make of him.
I would see that brave enemy;

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: My duty
Commands me to seek for him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Pray you do:
And bring him to our presence. Exit Gonzaga.

sp.speaker: Ast●t.
sp.l: I must blast
His entertainment; may it please your excellency,
He is a man debauched, and for his riots
Cast off by the King my master, and that, I hope, is
A crime sufficient

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To you his subjects,
That like as your King likesEnter Gonzaga, Bertoldo, richly habited: Adorni.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: But not to us;
We must weigh with our own scale. This is he, ●are!
How soon mine eye had found him! what a port
He bears! how well his bravery becomes him!
A prisoner! nay, a princely suitor rather!
But I am too sudden.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Madam, 'twas his suit,
Unsent for, to present his service to you,
Ere his departure.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: With what majesty
He bears himself!

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: The devil I think supplies him,
Ransomed, and thus rich too!

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You ill deserveFerdinand kneeling, kisses her hand.
The favour of our hand; we are not well,
Give us more air. She descends suddenly

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What sudden qualm is this?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: That lifted yours against me.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: Thus once more,
I sue for pardon

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sure his lips are poisoned,
And through those veins, force passage to my heartAside.
Which is already seized upon.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: I wait, madam,
To know what your commands are; my designs
Exact me in another place.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Before
You have our licence to depart; if manners,
Civility of manners cannot teach you
T'attend our leisure, I must tell you, sir,
That you are still our prisoner, nor had you
Commission to free him.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: How's this, madam?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You were my substitute, and wanted power
Without my warrant to dispose of him.
I will pay back his ransom ten times over,
Rather than quit my interest.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: This is
Against the law of arms.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But not of love:Aside.
Why, hath your entertainment, sir, been such
In your restraint, that with the wings of fear
You would fly from it?

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: I know no man, madam,
Enamoured of his fetters, or delighting
In cold or hunger, or that would in reason
Prefer straw in a dungeon, before
A down bed in a palace.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How, come nearer;
Was his usage such?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Yes, and it had been worse,
Had I foreseen this.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O thou mis-shaped monster!
In thee it is confirmed, that such as have
No share in nature's bounties, know no pity
To such as have 'em look on him with my eyes,
And answer then, whether this were a man,
Whose cheeks of lovely fullness should be made
A prey to meager famine? or these eyes
whose every glance store Cupid's emptied quiver,
To be dimmed with tedious watching? or these lips,
These ruddy lips, of whose fresh colour, cherries
And roses were but copies, should grow pale
For want of nectar? or these legs that bear
A burden of more worth, then is supported
By Atlas wearied shoulders, should be cramped
With the weight of iron? O I could dwell ever
On this description!

sp.speaker: Bertoldo.
sp.l: Is this in derision
Or pity of me?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: In your charity
Believe me innocent. Now you are my prisoner
You shall have fairer quarter, you will shame
The place where you have been, should you now leave it
Before you are recovered. I'll conduct you
To more convenient lodgings, and it shall be
My care to cherish you. Repine who dare;
It is our will. You'll follow me?

sp.speaker: Bertoldo.
sp.l: To the centre,
Such a Sibylla guiding me. Exeunt Aurelia, Bertoldo

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Who speaks first?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We stand, as we had seen Medusa's head! All amazed.

sp.speaker: Pierio.
sp.l: I know not what to think, I am so amazed!

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Amazed! I am thunderstruck!

sp.speaker: Jacom.
sp.l: We are enchanted,
And this is some illusion.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: Heaven forbid!
In dark despair, it shows a beam of hope.
Contain thy joy, Adorni.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: Such a Princess,
And of so long experienced reservedness
Break forth, and on the sudden, into flashes
Of more than doubted looseness.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: They come again,
Smiling, as I live: his arm circling her waist:
I shall run mad: some fury hath possessed her.
If I speak, I may be blasted. Ha, I'll mumble
A prayer or two, and cross myself, and then
Though the devil fart fire, have at him.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Let not, sir,
The violence of my passions nourish in you
An ill opinion; or grant my carriage
Out of the road, and garb of private women,
'Tis still done with decorum. As I am
A Princess, what I do, is above censure,
And to be imitated.

sp.speaker: Bertoldo.
sp.l: Gracious madam,
Vouchsafe a little pause, for I am so rapt
Beyond myself, that till I have collected
My scattered faculties, I cannot tender
My resolution.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Consider of it,
I will not be long from you,Bertoldo walking by musing.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Pray I cannot!
This cursed object strangles my devotion!
I must speak, or I burst. Pray you fair lady,
If you can in courtesy, direct me to
The chaste Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Are you blind? who are we?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: Another kind of thing. Her blood was governed
By her discretion, and not ruled her reason
The reverence and majesty of Juno
Shined in her looks, and coming to the camp,
Appeared a second Pallas. I can see
No such divinities in you. If I
Without offence may speak my thoughts, you are,
As it were, a wanton Helen.

sp.speaker: Aurelia.
sp.l: Good, ere long
You shall know me better.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why, if you are Aurelia's
How shall I dispose of the soldier?

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: May it please you
To hasten my dispatch?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Prefer your suits
Unto Bertoldo, we will give him hearing,
And you'll find him your best advocate. Exit Aurelia

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: This is rare!

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What are we come to?

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Grown up in a moment
A favourite!

sp.speaker: Ferdi.
sp.l: He does take state already.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, it cannot be, yet but Camiola,
There is no stop between me and a crown,
Than my ingratitude! A sin in which
All sins are comprehended! Aid me virtue,
Or I am lost.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: May it please your excellence
Second me, sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Then my so horrid oaths,
And hell. deep imprecations made against it.

sp.speaker: Astu.
sp.l: The King your brother will thank you for th'advancement
Of his affairs

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: And yet who can hold out
Against such batteries, as her power and greatness
Raise up against my weak defences!

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Sir,Enter Aurelia.
Do you dream waking, slight, she's here again.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Walks she on woollen feet!

sp.speaker: Aureli.
sp.l: You dwell too long
In your deliberation, and come
With a cripple's pace to that which you should fly to

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is confessed, yet why should I to win
From you, that hazard all to my poor nothing,
By false play send you off a looser from me?
I'm already too too much engaged
To the King my brother's anger; and who knows
But that his doubts, and politic fears, should you
Make me his equal, may draw war upon
Your territories, were that breach made up
I should with joy embrace, what now I fear
To touch but with due reverence.

sp.speaker: Aureli.
sp.l: That hinderance
Is easily removed. I owe the King
For a royal visit which I straight will pay him,
And having first reconciled you to his favour,
A dispensation shall meet with us,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: On this book seal it.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What hand and lip too, than the bargain's sure,
You have no employment for me?

sp.speaker: Aureli
sp.l: Yes Gonzaga,
Provide a royal ship.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: A ship? Saint John,
Whither are we bound now?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You shall know hereafter,
My lord your pardon, for my too much trenching upon your patience.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Camiola. Whispers to Bertoldo

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How do you

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Indisposed, but I attend you.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Adorn
sp.l: The heavy curse that waits on perjury,
And foul ingratitude, pursue thee ever.
Yet why from me this? In this breach of faith
My loyalty finds reward! what poisons him
Proves mithridate to me! I have performed
All she commanded punctually, and now
In the clear mirror of my truth, she may
Behold his falsehood. O that I had wings
To bear me to Palermo! This once known,
Must change her love into a just disdain,
And work her to compassion of my pain.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. V.
div.stage: Sylli. Camiola. Clarinda. At several doors.

sp.speaker: Sy●●●.
sp.l: Undone! undone! poor I that whilom was
The top and ridge of my house, am on the sudden
Turned to the pitifullest animal
Of the lineage of the Syllies!

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The King! break girdle, break!

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: Why? what of him?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Hearing how far you doted on my person,
Growing envious of my happiness, and knowing
His brother, nor his favourite Fulgentio,
Could get a sheep's eye from you, I being present,
Is come himself a suitor, with the awl
Of his authority to bore my nose,
And take you from me, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do not roar so;
The King!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The King! yet loving Sylli is not
So sorry for his own, as your misfortune,
If the King should carry you, or you bear him,
What a looser should you be? He can but make you
A Queen, and what a simple thing is that
To the being my lawful spouse. The world can never
Afford you such a husband.

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: I believe you,
But how are you sure the King is so inclined?
Did not you dream this?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: With these eyes I saw him
Dismiss his train, and lightning from his coach,
Whispering Fulgentio in the ear.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If so
I guess the business

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: It can be no other
But to give me the bob, that being a matter
Of main importance, yonder they are, I dare not
Be seen, I am so desperate, if you forsake me,Exit Rob. Ful.
Send me word that I may provide a willow garland
To wear when I drown myself. O Sylli, o Sylli! Exit crying

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: It will be worth your pains sir to observe
The constancy and bravery of her spirit,
Though great men tremble at your frowns, I dare
Hazard my head, your majesty set off
With terror, cannot fright her.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: May she answer
My expectation.

sp.speaker: Fulg●n.
sp.l: There she is.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My knees thus
Bent to the earth (While my vows are sent upward
For the safety of my sovereign) pay the duty
Due for so great an honour, in this favour
Done to your humblest handmaid.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: You mistake me,
I come not (Lady) that you may report,
The King to do you honour, made your house
(He being there) his court, but to correct
Your stubborn disobedience. A pardon
For that, could you obtain it, were well purchased
With this humility.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: A pardon sir?
Till I am conscious of an offence.
I will not wrong my innocence to beg one,
What is my crime sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Look on him I favour,
By you scorned and neglected.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Is that all sir.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: No minion, though that were too much. How can you
Answer the setting on your desperate bravo
To murder him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: With your leave, I must not kneel sir.
While I reply to this: but thus rise up
In my defence, and tell you as a man
(Since when you are unjust, the deity
which you may challenge as a King, parts from you
'Twas never read in holy writ, or moral,
That subjects on their loyalty were obliged
To love their sovereign's vices, your grace, sir,
To such an undeserver is no virtue.

sp.speaker: Fulg●n.
sp.l: What think you now sir?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Say you should love wine,
You being the King, and cause I am your subject,
Must I beever drunk? Tyrants, not Kings
By violence, from humble vassals force
The liberty of their souls. I could not love him
And to compel affection, as I take it,
Is not found in your prerogative.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Excellent virgin!
How I admire her confidence

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He complains
Of wrong done him: but he no more a King,
Unless you do me right. Burn your decrees,
And of your laws and statutes make a fire
To thaw frozen numbness of delinquents,
If he escape unpunished. Do your edicts
Call it death in any man that breaks into
Another's house to rob him, though of trifles
And shall Fulgentio your Fulgentio live?
Who hath committed more than sacrilege
In the pollution of my clear fame
By his malicious slanders

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Have you done this?
Answer truly on your life.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: In the heat of blood
Some such thing I reported.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Out of my sight,
For I vow, if by true penitence thou win
This injured lady to sue out thy pardon,
Thy grave is digged already.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: By my own folly
I have made a fair hand of't,Exit Fulgen.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You shall know lady
while I wear a crown, justice shall use her sword
To cut offenders off, though nearest to us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ay, now you show whose deputy you are,
I now I bathe your feet with tears, it cannot
Be censured superstition.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You must rise.
Rise in our favour, and protection ever:Kisses her

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Happy are subjects when the prince is still
Guided by justice, not his passionate will. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth act.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You see how tender I am of the quiet
And peace of your affection, and what great ones
I put off in your favour.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: You do wisely.
Exceeding wisely! and when I have said,
I thank you for't, be happy.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And good reason,
In having such a blessing.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: When you have it,
Bat the bait is not yet ready. Stay the time,
While I triumph by myself, King, by your leave,
I have wiped your royal nose, without a napkin,
You may cry willow, willow, for your brother,
I'll only say go by; for my fine favourite,
He may gra●●, where b● 〈◊〉, ●is lips may water
Like a puppy's o'er a frumenty p●t, while Sylli
Out of his two-leaved cherry-stone dish drinks nectar
I cannot hold out any longer; heaven forgive me,
'Tis not the first oath, I have broke, I must take
A little for a preparative. Offers to kiss and embrace her.

sp.speaker: Ca●●
sp.l: By no means.
If you forswear yourself we shall not prosper.
I'll rather lose my longing.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Pretty soul!
How careful it is of me! let me buff yet
Thy little dainty foot for't: that I am sure
Is out of my oath.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Why, if thou canst dispense with't
So fair, I'll not be scrupulous; such a favour
My amorous shoemaker steals

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O most rare leather! Kisses her shoe often
I do begin at the lowest, but in time
I may grow higher.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Fie, you dwell too long there!
Rise, prithee riseEnter Clarinda hast●ly

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O I am up already.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How I abuse my hours! what news with thee now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Off with that gown, 'tis mine, mine by your promise
Signior Ador. is returned! now upon entrance;
Off with it, off with it, madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Be not so hasty,
When I go to bed 'tis thine.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You have my grant too;
But do you hear lady, though I give way to this,
You must hereafter ask my leave before
You part with things of moment.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Very good,
When I am yours, I will be governed.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Sweet obedience! Ent. Ador.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You are well returned.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I wish that the success
Of my service had deserved it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Lives Bertoldo?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Yes, and returned with safety.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis not then
In the power of fate to add to, or take from
My perfect happiness: and yet he should
Have made me his first visit. Ador so I think too
But he

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Dar'st not appear, I being present,
That's his excuse, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Speak, where is he?
With whom? who hath deserved more from him? or
Can be of equal merit? I in this
Do not except the King.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: He's at the palace
With the Duchess of Sienna. One coach brought 'em hither.
Without a third. He's very gracious with her,
You may conceive the rest.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My jealous fears
Make me to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Pray you dismiss
Signior wisdom, and I'll make relation to you
Of the particulars.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Servant, I would have you
To haste unto the court.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I will outrun
A footman for your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There observe
The Duchess train and entertainment.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Fear not,
I will discover all that is of weight
To the liveries of her pages, and her footmen.
This is fit employment for me. Exit Syl.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Gracious with
The Duchess! sure you said so?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I will use
All possible brevity to inform you, madam,
Of what was trusted to me, and discharged
With faith and loyal duty.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I believe it
You ransomed him, and supplied his wants imagine
That is already spoken; and-what vows
Of service he made to me is apparent;
His joy of me, and wonder too perspicuous;
Does not your story end so?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Would the end
had answered the beginning, in a word,
Ingratitude, and perjury at the height
Cannot express him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Take heed.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Truth is armed
And can defend itself. It must out, madam.
I saw, the presence full, the amorous Duchess
Kiss and embrace him, on his part accepted
With equal ardour, and their willing hands
No sooner joined, but a remove was published,
And put in execution.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The proofs are
Too pregnant. O Bertoldo!

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: He's not worth
Your sorrow, madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Tell me, when you saw this
Did not you grieve as I do now to hear it?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: His precipice from goodness raising mine,
And serving as a foil to set my faith off,
I had little reason.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In this you confess
The devilish malice of your disposition.
As you were a man, you stood bound to lament it,
And not in flattery of false your hopes
To glory in it: when good men pursue
The path marked out by virtue, the blessed saints
With joy look on it, and seraphic angels
Clap their celestial wings in heavenly plaudits,
To be a scene of grace so well presented,
The fiends and men made up of envy mourning;
Where as now on the contrary as far
As their divinity can partake of passion,
With me they weep, beholding a fair temple
Built in Bertoldo's loyalty turned to ashes
By the flames of his inconstancy, the damned
Rejoicing in the object: 'tis not well
In you Adorni.

sp.speaker: Adorni.
sp.l: What a temper dwells
In this rare virgin, can you pity him
That hath shown none to you?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I must not be
Cruel by his example, you perhaps,
Except now I should seek recovery
Of what I have lost by tears, and with bent knees
Beg his compassion. No; my towering virtue
From the assurance of my merit scorns
To stoop so low. I'll take a nobler course,
And confident in the justice of my cause,
The King his brother, and new mistress, judges,
Ravish him from her arms, you have the contract
In which he swore to marry her?

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: 'Tis here madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He shall be then against his will my husband,
And when I have him, I'll so use him, doubt not,
But that your honesty being unquestioned,
This writing with your testimony clears all.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: And buries me in the dark mists of error.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I'll presently to court, pray you give order
For my caroche.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: A cart for me were fitter
To hurry me to the gallowsExit Adorni

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O false men!
Inconstant! perjured! my good angel help me
In these my extremities! Enter syll.

sp.speaker: Syl●i.
sp.l: If you ever will see brave sight,
Lose it not now. Bertoldo, and the Duchess
Are presently to be married. There's such pomp
And preparation.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If I marry, 'tis
This day or never.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Why with all my heart,
Though I break this, I'll keep the next oath I make
And then it is quit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Follow me to my cabinet,
You know my confessor, father Paulo?

sp.speaker: Syll.
sp.l: Yes. Shall he
Do the feat for us?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will give in writing
directions to him, and attire myself
Like a virgin-bride, and something I will do
That shall deserve men's praise, and wonder too.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: And I to make all know, I am not shallow
Will have my points of cochineal and yellow. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Ii.
div.stage: Astutio. Gonzaga. Roderigo. Jacomo. Pierio. Roberto. Bertoldo. Aurelia. Bishop. with attendants.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: Had our division been greater, madam,
Your clemency, the wrong being done to you
In pardon of it, like the rod of concord
Must make a perfect union, once more
With a brotherly affection we receive you
Into our favour. Let it be your study
Hereafter to deserve this blessing, far
Beyond your merit.

sp.speaker: Bert●l.
sp.l: As the Princess grace
To me is without limit, my endeavours
With all obsequiousness to serve her pleasures
Shall know no bounds, nor will I being made
Her husband, forget the duty that
I owe her as a servant.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I expect not
But fair equality, since I well know
If that superiority be due
'Tis not to me, when you are made my consort
All the prerogatives of my high birth cancelled
I'll practise the obedience of a wife,
And freely pay it. Queens themselves, if they
Make choice of their inferiors, only aiming
To feed their sensual appetites, and to reign
Over their husbands, in some kind commit
authorised whoredom, nor will I be guilty
In my intent of such a crime.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: This done,
As it is promised, madam, may well stand for
A precedent to great women: but when once
The griping hunger of desire is cloyed,
(And the poor fool advanced, brought on his knee
Most of your eagle breed, I'll not say all
(Ever excepting you) challenge again,
What in hot blood they parted from.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You are ever.
An enemy of our sex, but you I hope sir
Have better thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I dare not entertain
An ill one of your goodness.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: To my power
I will enable him to prevent all danger
Envy can raise against your choice. One word more
Touching the articles. Enter Ful. Cam. Syl. Ador.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: In you alone
Lie all my hopes, you can or kill or save me,
But pity in you, will become you better,
(Though I confess in justice 'tis denied me)
Then too much rigor.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will make your peace
As far as it lies in me, but must first
Labour to right myself.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Or add or alter
What you think fit. In him I have my all,
Heaven make me thankful for him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: On to the temple

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Stay royal sir, and as you are a King
Erect one here, in doing justice to
An injured maid.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O I am blasted!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have given some proof, sweet lady, of my promptness
To do you right, you need not therefore doubt me,
And rest assured, that this great work dispatched,
You shall have audience and satisfaction
to all you can demand.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To do me justice
Exacts your present care, and can admit
Of no delay. If e'er my cause be heard
In favour of your brother, you go on sir,
Your sceptre cannot right me. He's the man,
The guilty man, whom I accuse, and you
Stand bound in duty, as you are supreme,
To be impartial. Since you are a judge,
As a delinquent, look on him, and not
As on a brother; justice painted blind
Infers, her ministers are obliged to hear
The cause and truth, the judge determine of it,
And not swayed, or by favour, or affection,
By a false gloss, or wrested comment alter
The true intent, and letter of the law.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nor will I madam,

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You seem troubled, sir,

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: His colour changes too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The alteration
Grows from his guilt. The goodness of my cause
Begets such confidence in me, that I bring
No hired tongue to plead for me, that with gay
Rhetorical flourishes may palliate
That, which stripped naked, will appear deformed.
I stand here, mine own advocate; and my truth
Delivered in the plainest language, will
Make good itself, nor will I, if the King
Give suffrage to it, but admit of you,
My greatest enemy, and this stranger prince,
To sit assistants with him.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I ne'er wronged you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In your knowledge of the injury, I believe it,
Nor will you in your justice, when you are
Acquainted with my interest in this man
Which I lay claim to.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: Let us take our seats,
What is your title to him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: By this contract
Sealed solemnly before a reverend man,
I challenge him for my husband.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Ha. was I
Sent for the friar, for this? O Sylli! Sylli!
Some cordial, or I faint.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: This writing is
Authentical.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: But done in heat of blood,
(Charmed by her flatteries, as no doubt he was)
To be dispensed with.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Add this, if you please,
The distance and disparity between
Their births and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What can innocence hope for
When such as sit her judges, are corrupted!
Disparity of birth, or fortune urge you?
Or Siren charms? or at his best in me,
Wants to deserve him? Call some few days back,
And as he was, consider him, and you
Must grant him my inferior. Imagine
You saw him now in fetters with his honour,
His liberty lost; with her black wings despair
Circling his miseries, and his Gonzaga.
Trampling on his afflictions; the great sum
Proposed for his redemption; the King
Forbidding payment of it; this near kinsmen,
With his protesting followers, and friends,
Falling off from him; by the whole world forsaken;
Dead to all hope, and buried in the grave
Of his calamities, and then weigh duly
What she deserved (Whose merits now are doubted)
That as his better angel in her bounties
Appeared unto him, his great ransom paid,
His wants, and with a prodigal hand supplied,
Whether then being my manumised slave,
He owed not himself to me?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: In his silence 'tis acknowledged

sp.speaker: Gonzag.
sp.l: If you want
A witness to this purpose, I'll depose it:

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If I have dwelled too long on my deservings
To this unthankful man, pray you pardon me,
The cause required it. And though now I add
A little in my painting to the life
His barbarous ingratitude, to deter,
Others from imitation, let it meet with
A fair interpretation. This serpent,
Frozen to numbness, was no sooner warmed
In the bosom of my pity, and compassion,
But in return, he ruined his preserver
The prints the irons had made in his flesh
Still ulcerous; but all that I had done
(My benefits in sand, or water written)
As they had never been, no more remembered.
And on what ground; but his ambitious hopes
To gain this Duchess favour,

sp.speaker: Aurelia.
sp.l: Yes, the object,
Look on it better (Lady) may excuse
The charge of his affection.

sp.speaker: Camiol.
sp.l: The object
In what? forgive me, modesty, if I say
You look upon your form in the false glass
Of flattery, and self love, and that deceives you,
That you were a Duchess, as I take it, was not
Charactered on your face, and that not seen,
For other feature, make all these that are
Experienced in women, judges of 'em,
And if they are not parasites, they must grant
For beauty without art, though you storm at it,
I may take the right hand file.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Well said i'faith;
I see fair women on no terms will yield
Priority in beauty.

sp.speaker: Camiol.
sp.l: Down proud heart!
Why do I rise up in defence of that,
which, in my cherishing of it hath undone me.
No madam, I recant, you are all beauty,
Goodness, and virtue, and poor I not worthy
As a soil to set you off; enjoy your conquest
But do not tyrannize. Yet as I am
In my lowness from your height, you may look on me,
And in your suffrage to me, make him know
That though to all men else I did appear
The shame and scorn of women, he stands bound
To hold me as her masterpiece.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: By my life
You have shown yourself of such an abject temper,
So poor, and low conditioned, as I grieve for
Your nearness to me.

sp.speaker: F●rd..
sp.l: I am changed in my
Opinion of you lady, and profess
The virtues of your mind, an ample fortune
For an absolute monarch.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Since you are resolved
To damn yourself, in your forsaking of
Your noble order for a woman, do it
For this. You may search through the world, and meet not
With such another phoenix.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: On the sudden
I feel all fires of love quenched in the water
Of compassion, make your peace; you have
My free consent; for here I do disclaim
All interest in you: and to further your
Desires, fair maid, composed of worth and honour,
The dispensation procured by me,
Freeing Bertoldo from his vow, makes way
To your embraces.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: O, how have I strayed,
And wilfully, out of the noble tract
Marked me by virtue! Till now, I was never
Truly a prisoner; to excuse my late
Captivity, I might allege the malice
Of fortune; you that conquered me confessing
courage in my defence was no way wanting
But now I have surrendered up my strengths
Into the power of vice, and on my forehead
Branded with mine own hand in capital letters
Disloyal, and ingrateful, though barred from
Humane society, and hissed into
Some desert never yet haunted with the curses
Of men and women, sitting as a judge
Upon my guilty self, I must confess
It justly falls upon me, and one tear
Shed in compassion of my sufferings more.
Then I can hope for.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This compunction
For the wrong that you have done me, though you should
Fix here, and your true sorrow move no further,
Will in respect I loved once, make these eyes
Two springs of sorrow for you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: In your pity
My cruelty shows more monstrous, yet I am not,
Though most ingrateful, grown to such a height
Of impudence, as in my wishes only
To ask your pardon. If as now I fall
Prostrate before your feet, you will vouchsafe
To act your own revenge, treading upon me
As a viper eating through the bowels of
Your benefits, to whom with liberty
I owe my being, 'twill take from the burden
That now is insupportable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray you rise,
As I wish peace, and quiet to my soul
I do forgive you heartily, yet excuse me:
Though I deny myself a blessing that
By the favour of the Duchess seconded,
With your submission is offered to me
Let not the reason I allege for't grieve you,
You have been false once. I have done. And if
When I am married (As this day I will be)
As a perfect sign of your atonement with me
You wish me joy, I will receive it for
full satisfaction of all obligations
In which you stand bound to me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I will do it,
And what's more, in despite of sorrow, live
To see myself undone, beyond all hope
To be made up again.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: My blood begins
To come to my heart again.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray you signior Syl.
Call in the holy friar. He's prepared
For finishing the work.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I knew I was
The man. Heaven make me thankful

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Astu.
sp.l: His father was the banker of Palermo,
And this the heir of his great wealth, his wisdom
Was not hereditary.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Though you know me not,
Your majesty owes me a round sum, I have
A seal, or two to witness, yet if you please
To wear my colours, and dance at my wedding
I'll never sue you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And I'll grant your suit,

sp.speaker: Syl●
sp.l: Gracious madonna, noble, general,
Brave captains and my quondam rivals wear 'em
Since I am confident you dare not harbour
A thought, but that way currant.Exit

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: For my part
I cannot guess the issue. Enter Syl. with

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Do your duty,
And with all speed you can, you may dispatch us.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.l: Thus as a principal ornament to the church
I seize her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Ro●..
sp.l: So young and so religious.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: She has forsook the world.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: And Silly too,
I shall run mad. Syl thrust o●●

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hence with the fool, proceed sir

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Look on this maid of honour now
Truly honoured in her vow
She pays to heaven, vain delight
By day, or pleasure of, the night,
She no more thinks of this fair hair
(Favours for great Kings to wear)
Mun now be shorn. Her rich array
Changed into a homely grey.
The dainties with which she was fed
And her proud flesh pampered,
Must not be tasted, from the spring,
For wine cold water we will bring
And with fasting mortify
The feasts of sensuality.
Her jewels, beads, and she must look
Not in a glass, but holy book;
To teach her the ne'er erring way
To immortality. O may
She as she purposes to be
A child new born to piety,
Persever in in it, and good men
With saints and angels say amen

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This is the marriage! this the port! to which
My vows must steer me, fill my spreading sails
With the pure wind of your devotions for me,
That I may touch the secure haven, where
Eternal happiness keeps her reside me,
Temptations to frailty never entering.
I am dead to the world, and thus dispose
Of what I leave behind me, and dividing
My state into three parts, I thus bequeath it.
The first to the fair nunnery, to which
I dedicate the last, and better part
Of my frail life; a second portion
To pious uses; and the third to thee
Adorni, for thy true and faithful service.
And ere I mistake lu●● farewell with hope
To find a gran●, may suit to you is that
You would for my sake pardon this young man
and to his merits love him, and no further.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I thus confirm it. Gives his hand to Fulgen. to Bertoldo

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: And as ere you hope
Like me to be made happy, I conjure you
To reassume your order; and in fighting
Bravely against the enemies of our faith
Redeem your mortgaged honour.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I restore thisThe white cross.
Once more brothers in arms,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I'll live and die so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To you my pious wishes. And to end
All differences, great sir I beseech you
To be an arbitrator, and compound
The quarrel, long continuing between
The Duke and Duchess.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: I'll take it into
My special care.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am then at rest, now fatherExeunt Paulo. And Camiola.
Conduct me where you please.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: She well deserves
Her name, the maid of honour! May she stand
To all posterity, a fair example,
For noble maids to imitate. Since to live
In wealth and pleasure is common; but to part with
Such poisoned baits is rare, there being nothing
Upon this stage of life to be commended,
Though well begun, till it be fully ended. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
